fact_list.fact_text: Maintain your vehicle in a roadworthy condition.
You should pay attention to maintenance matters to prevent accidents.
Keep your tyres up to the correct pressure.
Replace tyres with treads less than 1.6mm in depth.
Smooth or bald tyres can cause skids during hard braking.
Have the brake system checked regularly, especially hydraulic brakes, for any leakage of brake fluid.
The steering assembly of your car should be checked regularly and kept in good condition.
Check for vibration or looseness in the steering mechanism or wheels that are out of alignment.
Faulty steering can be as dangerous as a car being driven by a drunk driver.
Check all your vehicle lights regularly.
Keep the direction indicators functional and check them frequently.
Signal lights that fail to light up when required can cause accidents.
Ensure your horn is in working order.
Check the level of coolant in the radiator regularly.
Most modern cars have a coolant reservoir with indicator markings for correct levels.
Check the coolant level when the engine is cool, especially for cars without coolant reservoirs.
Radiator coolant is pressurised when hot, so ensure the engine is cool before opening the radiator cap.
Maintain enough oil in the engine and change oil periodically.
Check the oil level using the dip-stick.
Keep windscreen wipers in good condition.
Dirty windscreens and faulty windscreen wipers hinder vision during rain.
Keep the battery and its terminals clean.
Ensure connections at the battery terminals are securely tightened.
Check the battery water level for non-maintenance-free batteries, and refill with distilled or commercial battery water below the low level.
Refilling with tap water shortens battery life considerably.
Vehicles must be maintained to eliminate excessive smoke and noise emissions.
Excessive smoke and noise are nuisances and hazardous to health.
Check the exhaust system regularly.
Exhaust fumes leaking into the passenger compartment can lead to carbon-monoxide poisoning.
